# Not All Law Firms Are Created Equal: Some Provide Fewer Benefits Which Can Hurt Your Ability To Pay Off Student Loans
## Will working at a smaller law firm put you at a disadvantage when trying to pay down your debt?
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onOctober 25, 2017 at 11:29 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/not-all-law-firms-are-created-equal-some-provide-fewer-benefits-which-can-hurt-your-ability-to-pay-off-student-loans/&text=Not%20All%20Law%20Firms%20Are%20Created%20Equal:%20Some%20Provide%20Fewer%20Benefits%20Which%20Can%20Hurt%20Your%20Ability%20To%20Pay%20Off%20Student%20Loans)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/not-all-law-firms-are-created-equal-some-provide-fewer-benefits-which-can-hurt-your-ability-to-pay-off-student-loans/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/not-all-law-firms-are-created-equal-some-provide-fewer-benefits-which-can-hurt-your-ability-to-pay-off-student-loans/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw firms are known for taking care of their associates, and attorneys at these shops are pampered in unbelievable ways.  Large firms typically provide many fringe benefits including subsidies for buying phones, free rides home from the office late at night, free meals, and paying all manner of bar fees and other professional expenses.  Indeed, Biglaw firms truly have a “cradle to grave” system in which recent law school graduates receive stipends to study for the bar, and departing attorneys get generous severance packages on their way out.

However, not all law firms offer such benefits, and this can really affect one’s bottom line.  Of course, everyone probably understands that smaller law firms do not provide the more extravagant fringe benefits that one can expect at a large firm.  However, many smaller law firms do not pay for some of the most basic costs associated with being an attorney.  Having to pay for professional expenses yourself, and not being able to take advantage of other fringe benefits, can really hurt one’s ability to save money and pay off student loans.  As such, it is important to consider some important perks and benefits when contemplating where to work.

Although it is usually assumed that all law firms pay bar membership fees for attorneys, some firms do not provide this benefit.  Indeed, while working at my first job after leaving Biglaw, I was responsible for paying all of my own bar membership fees.  In addition, I also had to pay for the fees associated with joining the bar of a federal court, even though I was required to be a member of that bar to work on some of the matters assigned to me by my employer.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
These expenses added up quickly.  I am a member of two state bars, and I had to pay hundreds of dollars to gain admission to a federal bar.  One year, I paid nearly $1,000 in bar membership fees!  This is a lot of money that could have been devoted to paying down my student loans, and one should try to work at a firm that will cover these expenses to avoid going out-of-pocket for these costs.  In addition, it is best to gain admission to federal bars while working in Biglaw, since then your firm will likely cover the cost.  If you later end up working at a firm that does not pay for these expenses, you will already be admitted to federal bars and will not have to cover this cost yourself.

In addition, although Biglaw firms typically pay for CLEs, and many even have in-house CLE programs, many smaller law firms will not pay for CLE classes.  Indeed, while working at my first job after leaving Biglaw, my firm did not pay for CLE classes, and I had to pay hundreds of dollars a year just to make sure that I fulfilled all of the requirements to keep my law licenses.  There are many ways you can obtain CLE credits on the cheap, and some outlets even offer free CLE classes.  However, one should try to work at a firm that covers these costs so that one can save money to devote more cash toward student loans.  In addition, anyone hoping to leave Biglaw should take care of CLE credits while employed at a larger firm just in case this cost is not covered by your new firm.

Many smaller law firms also do not pay for the costs associated with being a member of a state or local bar association.  I had to let all of my memberships in bar associations lapse while working at my first job after leaving Biglaw, since my firm did not pay for these expenses, and I wanted to save my money to pay down student loans.  Not paying for associates to become members of bar associations is somewhat “penny wise and dollar foolish,” since there are many benefits to joining these organizations, including access to cheap legal research platforms, opportunities to network, and other advantages.  However, the reality is that many smaller law firms do not pay for these costs, and one should consider this when choosing which firm to work at after leaving Biglaw.

After all this “doom and gloom” about perks that smaller law firms might not offer, I wanted to relate one advantage of working at some smaller shops that could benefit your bottom line when paying off student loans.  Although most Biglaw firms (with some notable exceptions) have lockstep bonus structures in which associates with similar experience get a set bonus, many smaller firms offer bonuses based on the number of hours an associate bills.  As a result, an associate who bills an insane number of hours at a smaller law firm might receive a bigger bonus than a similarly-situated associate in Biglaw.  If you are willing to put in extra hours, such bonus systems can really benefit someone trying to pay down student loans, and this perk should be researched when considering employment opportunities.

All told, there are many aspects about working at smaller law firms that can affect your ability to save money to pay off student loans.  However, with some research and consideration, you can land at a firm that will put you in the best position to pay down your student debt.

Jordan Rothman is the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](http://studentdebtdiaries.com), a personal finance website discussing how he paid off all $197,890.20 of his college and law school student loans over 46 months of his late 20s. You can reach him at [Jordan@studentdebtdiaries.com](mailto:Jordan@studentdebtdiaries.com).

## * "[What did Rudy say](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-giuliani-time-rudy-ritualistically-suicides-one-case-to-try-to-save-trump-from-another/)? Oh. OK, so, you see, the thing is, Cohen was paid back, but through his monthly retainer so I didn't know he was paying hush money to porn stars that I definitely didn't sleep with because that might trigger an out in my prenup... are we done here?" [[Twitter](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/991992302267785216)] * A look at Biglaw firms still owed big bucks by bankrupt clients. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/05/01/gibson-brands-headlines-latest-bankruptcy-batch-of-big-law-creditors/)] * Yale Law is so far ahead of the curve, they've got 1Ls suing Jeff Sessions. [[Connecticut Law Tribune](https://www.law.com/ctlawtribune/2018/05/02/yale-law-students-take-sessions-to-court-over-flouted-guidance/)] * A webcam is drawing attention to the osprey nest on the roof of Oregon's Law School. Anything to keep attention off [the blackface-wearing professor they still employ](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/white-professor-who-wore-blackface-teaching-about-race-because-there-are-no-consequences-for-anything-anymore/)... [[Around the O](https://around.uoregon.edu/content/webcam-drawing-eyes-osprey-nest-above-uo-law-school)] * In case you were looking for another reason to feel revulsion over the Washington NFL team, the cheerleaders allege the team asked them to be literal escorts for wealthy sponsors on a trip to Costa Rica... that they didn't get paid for. [[CNN](http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2773918-redskins-cheerleaders-detail-13-trip-to-costa-rica-involving-topless-photo-shoot)] * Which law firms boast the best legal tech game? [[Legaltech News](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1039632/2nd-circ-revives-immigrants-suit-over-no-fly-list-placement)] * The Second Circuit is bringing back the lawsuit over abuse of the no-fly list. The government allegedly dumped people on the no-fly list if they refused to be informants. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1039632/2nd-circ-revives-immigrants-suit-over-no-fly-list-placement)]

# Early Compensation Mover Proves It's Willing To Keep Playing The Salary 'Game'
## Biglaw firm plays the re-raise card.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 14, 2021 at 11:20 AMJune 15, 2021 at 11:10 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/mwe-re-raise-21/&text=Early%20Compensation%20Mover%20Proves%20It’s%20Willing%20To%20Keep%20Playing%20The%20Salary%20‘Game’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/mwe-re-raise-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/mwe-re-raise-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Waaaaaay back on Thursday, when the Biglaw compensation market moved to $200,000 for first-year associates, [thanks to Milbank](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/milbank-raises-21/), McDermott, Will & Emery [was the first firm to match the raises](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/we-have-our-first-match-of-the-new-biglaw-compensation-scale/), doing so within a matter of hours. But then [Davis Polk played spoiler](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/davis-polk-salary-21/), coming over the top of the Milbank scale.

But MWE is not to be deterred. On Friday, the firm announced a re-raise of associate salaries, with the below note, which, without explicitly confirming it, sure makes it seem like the they have more in the tank should another firm — cough Cravath cough — come back over the top:

We are so happy to be in a position to be able to reward our hardworking, best-in-class Associates in this way. We see your amazing level of commitment and know you are “all in” and very aligned with our plans to be the number one career accelerant in the legal profession.
Maybe the games continue or maybe we’re done: Who knows? What we hope for, at least, is that you enjoy your weekend and appreciate these brighter days.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  


In truth, we expected the re-raise. [That’s what happened in 2018](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/?rf=1) when Cravath came over the top of Milbank’s raises. There will almost certainly be more of the $200K scale firms moving to the $205K scale, they just might be waiting until… other big players in associate compensation make their move so they don’t have to issue a third compensation memo within a matter of days.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Raises”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Is Your Firm Keeping Pace With Cloud-Based eDiscovery?
## We want to hear your views on moving law firms to the cloud.
By [Above the Law and Everlaw](http://bit.ly/2y2v9fZ)  
onFebruary 23, 2021 at 12:12 PMFebruary 26, 2021 at 12:39 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/is-your-firm-keeping-pace-with-cloud-based-ediscovery/&text=Is%20Your%20Firm%20Keeping%20Pace%20With%20Cloud-Based%20eDiscovery?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/is-your-firm-keeping-pace-with-cloud-based-ediscovery/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/is-your-firm-keeping-pace-with-cloud-based-ediscovery/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Organizations that adopt cloud-based eDiscovery identify key information quickly amid what can often be chaotic and expansive document sets. 

These platforms promote seamless collaboration, optimize efficiencies across workflows, and provide better control and higher data security.

In partnership with our friends at the leading eDiscovery provider [Everlaw](http://bit.ly/2y2v9fZ), we’re fielding a brief [survey](http://bit.ly/3bLiv6j) to gain insight into how law firms are implementing and utilizing their eDiscovery platforms — whether in the cloud or on premise. 

[Click here ](http://bit.ly/3bLiv6j)to take the survey and see how your eDiscovery systems are keeping pace. 

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Cloud Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/cloud-technology/), [Content Syndication](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/content-syndication/), [eDiscovery](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/tag-ediscovery/), [Everlaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/everlaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Surveys](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/surveys/), [Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/technology/)

# The Law Schools Where The Most Graduates Got Jobs At Large Firms (2017)
## You don't necessarily need to go to a top law school to get a job at a top law firm.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 11, 2018 at 12:12 PMMay 11, 2018 at 11:19 AM
49
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-jobs-at-large-firms-2017/&text=The%20Law%20Schools%20Where%20The%20Most%20Graduates%20Got%20Jobs%20At%20Large%20Firms%20(2017))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-jobs-at-large-firms-2017/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-jobs-at-large-firms-2017/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Do you like money? Of course you do, you’ve got student loans to pay off. Do you like prestige? Obviously, you’re a Type A law student. If you’re like the majority of your colleagues and you’d like to embark upon upon a career path that’ll pad your wallet and get you in on the ground floor at a prestigious firm, then you’ll probably want to compete for a job at a large firm.

[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2018/04/25/law-grads-hiring-report-job-stats-for-the-class-of-2017/) produced several helpful charts based on law school employment data for the class of 2017. Today, we will take a look at one of the more interesting charts, the law schools that sent the highest percentage of their most recent graduating class into large firms with 100 or more lawyers. On this list, you’ll find a dazzling array of law schools from the T14, but we’re not here to tell you what you already know — that graduates of top law schools get top jobs. That being said, we’re going to dive a little deeper into the list and highlight the schools you may not realize are some of the top large-firm contenders. Here they are for your viewing pleasure:

- Fordham: 41.26 percent
- Howard: 29.13 percent
- Southern Methodist: 26.27 percent
- Indiana-Bloomington: 23.16 percent
- UC Hastings: 19.64 percent
- Cardozo: 18.84 percent
- Temple: 17.97 percent
- Brooklyn: 17.39 percent
- Catholic: 15.32 percent
- Detroit Mercy: 15.23 percent
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Click [here](https://www.law.com/2018/04/25/law-grads-hiring-report-job-stats-for-the-class-of-2017/) to see the rest of the law schools with the highest percentage of graduates employed in Biglaw jobs, plus other informative charts detailing the law schools with the highest percentage of graduates working in [federal clerkships](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-federal-clerkships-2017/), [state clerkships](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-state-clerkships-2017/?rf=1), and [government and public interest](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-where-the-most-graduates-got-government-public-interest-jobs-2017/), as well as the law schools with the most [unemployed](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-with-the-most-unemployed-graduates-2017/) and most [underemployed](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/the-law-schools-with-the-most-underemployed-graduates-2017/) graduates.

Are you a recent law school graduate who landed a job at a large firm? What did your law school do to help you? We’re interested in learning about your experiences — good or bad — and may anonymously feature some of your stories on Above the Law. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BLaw%20School%5D%20Biglaw%20Jobs), text us at (646) 820-8477, or tweet us [@atlblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog). Thanks!

# Another Firm Stuffs Their Associates' Pockets With Money!
## We love to see it!
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onDecember 13, 2023 at 2:10 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/another-firm-stuffs-their-associates-pockets-with-money/&text=Another%20Firm%20Stuffs%20Their%20Associates’%20Pockets%20With%20Money!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/another-firm-stuffs-their-associates-pockets-with-money/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/another-firm-stuffs-their-associates-pockets-with-money/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Nobody likes waiting for an expected compensation email while it seems every other peer firm is getting base salary increases and bonuses. Thankfully, the wait is over for Seward & Kissel! Here are the new numbers:





Congrats on making the big bucks! Looking to spread the joy? Consider sharing some of your windfall with the Brooklyn-based [Read718](https://www.read718.org/). Even the more boring parts of the job take their fair share of reading comprehension — what better way to pay it forward than helping kids understand the books (or PDFs) in front of them?

We like hearing about bonuses almost as much as you enjoy spending them. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. # Lawyers Should Get Work Product Right The First Time
## Fast and wrong is rarely preferred to slower and better.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJuly 26, 2023 at 3:15 PMJuly 26, 2023 at 1:03 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/lawyers-should-get-work-product-right-the-first-time/&text=Lawyers%20Should%20Get%20Work%20Product%20Right%20The%20First%20Time)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/lawyers-should-get-work-product-right-the-first-time/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/lawyers-should-get-work-product-right-the-first-time/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I used to work for a partner who always wanted work product to be drafted and delivered to him by associates as soon as possible. Even if there were no set deadlines that required such a quick delivery of the work product, the partner reasoned that if he had work product delivered from an associate sooner, he could better organize his reviewing and refining work. However, partners should not emphasize delivering work product fast if no external deadline requires it. Getting the work product right the first time is far better than getting it drafted as soon as possible.

Perhaps the main reason why it is important to get work product right the first time — even if this takes more time — is because lawyers often have the best chance to make the biggest impact on work product on the first draft they write. For instance, if a lawyer works on a lease, purchase contract, or any other commercial deal, they will have a much better chance at getting changes accepted by the other side if they raise those changes earlier in the negotiating process. Once parties start exchanging drafts of edits and revisions, it becomes much harder for changes to be accepted by all of the stakeholders.

When deals come to a conclusion, people are usually only willing to change minor details about the transaction as opposed to major deal terms. If lawyers rush when getting out an initial draft of documents, it is possible for attorneys to miss something major that they should have included in the documents in the first place. As a result, even if deals require quick turnarounds or other time pressures are present, it is important to get things right the first time so that matters are not forgotten that cannot be fixed later on.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Another reason why lawyers should get work product right the first time is because the lawyer may be judged on that work product without an understanding that it was produced on short notice. Most work product does not include a disclaimer noting that it was created in a short time and does not reflect an attorney’s full capabilities. Most people will simply look at work product and believe that it is either the best that a lawyer can do or is the type of work product that an attorney produces in the course of their business.

When a client sees errors in work product, they likely will not care whether the work product was produced in a short time. They will just see that their lawyer made mistakes, and this will alter the perception a client has of their counsel. Moreover, courts will usually not understand that a lawyer had little time to complete filings and will usually just think that a brief or other filing contains the best argument a lawyer could make on behalf of a client. Accordingly, lawyers should try to get extensions of litigation deadlines or other flexibility whenever possible so that they can do the work correctly rather than merely filing as soon as possible.

Another reason why you should get work product right the first time is because it might actually take more time and resources to edit work product that is bad when it is first circulated than if it was done properly the first time. This not only applies to when attorneys try to push materials out as quickly as possible but when the wrong personnel at a law firm takes a first stab at a project.

At many law firms, there is some pressure to keep associates busy with work, and partners may want to assign to associates projects that partners might be more qualified to handle so an associate has billable work. However, by the time a partner goes through the associate’s work, they might spend more time on a matter than if the partner had simply done the work the first time around. Of course, I am not saying that partners should never assign work to associates, and there are definitely projects that associates are very qualified to handle without the involvement of partners. However, partners should evaluate the total cost to a client in terms of delay and number of hours billed when determining if they should just complete the assignment right the first time.

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

# Top Firm To Pay Senior Associates Full Biglaw Salaries For Working In Yearlong Justice Fellowships
## Orrick is really putting its money where its mouth is when it comes to racial and social justice.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 22, 2021 at 3:15 PMOctober 22, 2021 at 12:20 PM
18
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/top-firm-to-pay-senior-associates-full-biglaw-salaries-for-working-in-yearlong-justice-fellowships/&text=Top%20Firm%20To%20Pay%20Senior%20Associates%20Full%20Biglaw%20Salaries%20For%20Working%20In%20Yearlong%20Justice%20Fellowships)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/top-firm-to-pay-senior-associates-full-biglaw-salaries-for-working-in-yearlong-justice-fellowships/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/top-firm-to-pay-senior-associates-full-biglaw-salaries-for-working-in-yearlong-justice-fellowships/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We wanted to do more than write a check. We asked ourselves what we could be doing. And pretty quickly we defaulted to the concept of partnering with organizations that were experts in facilitating change.

We saw the richness of the experience they had to learn and grow as lawyers and to learn more directly from organizations we admire. It is easy for organizations, in the moment, to make a commitment and close it over time. We wanted to make a lasting difference that was financially meaningful, had the energy required to make change and to give some of our best people the chance to be part of a new public-private partnership and have a real impact in the community.

— [Mitch Zuklie](https://www.orrick.com/people/8/5/e/mitchell-zuklie), chairman and CEO of Orrick, commenting on the firm’s Racial, Social & Economic Justice Fellowship Program, during an interview with the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/10/22/senior-associates-are-a-hot-commodity-orrick-is-lending-out-6-of-them-for-the-next-3-years/). For the past year, six senior Orrick associates have worked as fellows at [Howard University’s Thurgood Marshall Civil Rights Center](https://thurgoodmarshallcenter.howard.edu/), [NYU Law’s Policing Project](https://www.policingproject.org/), the [Lawyer’s Committee for Civil Rights Under Law](https://www.lawyerscommittee.org/), the [Law Foundation of Silicon Valley](https://www.lawfoundation.org/), [Common Future](https://www.commonfuture.co/), and [A New Way of Life](https://anewwayoflife.org/), all while earning their full Biglaw salaries and bonuses. Orrick is the first Biglaw firm to run any kind of full-salaried program like this, and recently decided to extend its fellowship initiative for the next three years.

# Yet Another Firm Ends Merger Talks With Stroock
## Always a bridesmaid, never a bride.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 27, 2023 at 10:42 AMOctober 27, 2023 at 9:12 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/yet-another-firm-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/&text=Yet%20Another%20Firm%20Ends%20Merger%20Talks%20With%20Stroock)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/yet-another-firm-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/yet-another-firm-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One month ago, Stroock announced that it was in talks with Pillsbury Winthrop, and the pair had [signed a non-exclusive letter of intent to merge](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/stroock-is-talking-to-another-am-law-100-firm-about-merging-but-its-not-exclusive/). If the proposed tie-up had been successful, it would have brought an international presence to Stroock. Unfortunately, those talks have come to an end, putting Stroock back on the singles market in its time of need.

Pillsbury offered a statement to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/26/pillsbury-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/) on why things didn’t pan out:

“We considered different options, including a combination and a lateral acquisition, but ultimately determined that we could not reach an agreement that adequately balanced Pillsbury’s long-term strategic objectives with the more immediate financial and other risks involved,” a Pillsbury representative said in an email statement Thursday.

The firm added: “We remain impressed with the quality of Stroock’s lawyers and wish them and their professional staff the very best.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Stroock has this to say about its latest merger failure: “Given our current options, after careful consideration, we also concluded that a Pillsbury-Stroock combination was not the right path for us. Pillsbury is a world-class firm with excellent people, and we wish them and their professional staff the best.”

All of Stroock’s most important financial metrics dropped in 2022 (gross revenue by ~8.8%, revenue per lawyer by ~2%, and profits per equity partner by ~7.5%). On top of its financial losses, the firm has been [leaking lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/partners-associates-staff-flee-biglaw-firm-after-merger-efforts-crumble/) like a sieve ever since it [broke up](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-merger-effort-crumbles/) with Nixon Peabody. Prior to that, the firm had gone so far as to [cut salaries and hours](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/stroock-reportedly-cut-pay-hours-as-it-struggled-to-find-merger-partner/) for senior staff members and [conduct layoffs](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/stroock-layoffs/) among its attorneys and staff. Given this backdrop, the firm does not seem to be in a very good place right now, so hopefully those “options” work out.

[Pillsbury Ends Merger Talks With Stroock](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/10/26/pillsbury-ends-merger-talks-with-stroock/) [American Lawyer]

# Third Major Biglaw Firm To Require 4 Days In Office
## Three Biglaw firms is a certified trend.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 11, 2023 at 1:43 PMJuly 12, 2023 at 11:10 AM
27
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/weil-gotshal-4-days-in-office/&text=Third%20Major%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Require%204%20Days%20In%20Office)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/weil-gotshal-4-days-in-office/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/weil-gotshal-4-days-in-office/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[Skadden](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/you-didnt-see-your-kids-before-the-pandemic-you-shouldnt-expect-to-see-them-now-says-elite-law-firm-partner/) started the trend, then [Davis Polk](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/davis-polk-4-day-office/) hopped on board. Today, Weil Gotshal informed attorneys they’ll have to be in the office four days a week, starting in September.

As [reported by](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/07/11/weil-gotshal-to-require-four-days-of-office-attendance/) Law.com, associates will be expected to be in the office Monday – Thursday. Additionally, associates and counsel will have 12 “flexible remote days” a year (they’ll get four flex days for the remainder of 2023 when the policy starts in the fall). Attorneys will also have the option to work remotely the last two weeks of August, the week of Thanksgiving, and the week between Christmas and New Year’s.

In announcing the policy change, the firm noted the benefits of in-person lawyering for training, professional development, and more:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“Over the past year, we have all seen the many benefits that come with people working regularly in-person — especially with the predictability of knowing people will be in consistently on the same days,” the email stated. “Training for our lawyers at all levels has benefited from the full return, as have mentorship, morale and professional development.”

The only real question is which other firms will take an iron-fist approach to office attendance. Now that three Biglaw firms are on board, it is officially a trend, and you’d best believe the industry will take notice.

As soon as you find out about office attendance plans at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.

# $100 Million Fraud & Money Laundering Suit Brought Against Biglaw Firm
## RICO less than sauve.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 17, 2022 at 1:57 PMOctober 18, 2022 at 10:02 AM
24
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/100-million-fraud-money-laundering-suit-brought-against-biglaw-firm/&text=$100%20Million%20Fraud%20&%20Money%20Laundering%20Suit%20Brought%20Against%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/100-million-fraud-money-laundering-suit-brought-against-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/100-million-fraud-money-laundering-suit-brought-against-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Dechert’s long-running Neil Gerrard headache continues.

It all started when the firm’s former white collar practice chief Gerrard began working for the Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation (he began working for ENRC at DLA Piper, but brought the engagement with him when he lateraled to Dechert). ENRC hired Gerrard to conduct an internal investigation into its Kazakhstan operations.

Given that, [during the time in question](https://www.gov.kz/memleket/entities/anticorruption/press/news/details/153783?lang=en#:~:text=Kazakhstan%20has%20for%20the%20first,in%202019%20(34%20points).), Kazakhstan scored a solid 3 out of 100 in the international corruption index, this was probably a prudent move for ENRC!

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This is the end of the prudent moves in this story.

Everyone knows that it’s important to set a budget in any legal engagement. ENRC planned on this matter costing around £400,000. The matter cost £13,000,000. Damn surge pricing!

The massive spike in costs came as the investigation ballooned to include inquiries into dealings in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Iran. Which, to be fair, also raise some red flags as business partners!

Though allegations arose that Gerrard referred to the billing model as “[rape mode](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-most-offensive-way-to-refer-to-biglaw-bills/)” casting doubt on the legitimacy of those inquiries. Ultimately, Gerrard got benchslapped for [making leaks to discredit his client](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/biglaw-partner-treated-client-as-cash-cow-gets-benchslapped-in-court-judgment/), seemingly in a bid to get them to hire him to help them out of the public jams created by those leaks? The last time we checked in on that case, Dechert had agreed to an interim $20 million payment.

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Now an unrelated [new lawsuit in the Southern District of New York](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2022/10/Dechert-Gerrard.pdf) against Dechert and Gerrard among others seeks “total damages in excess of $100 million” for obstruction, witness tampering, money laundering, mail and bank fraud, and… yes… doing the RICO.

[Farhad Azima](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farhad_Azima) claims Gerrard and Dechert colluded with others to target Azima after Azima sought to expose human rights abuses committed by a Dechert client. Per the complaint:

Dechert played a central role in the Enterprise’s affairs and criminal activity. To carry out its scheme, Gerrard and the Enterprise relied upon Dechert’s infrastructure, partners, employees, financial resources, and reputation. Dechert received millions of dollars in fees as a direct result of the Enterprise’s continuing campaign of criminal conduct. Dechert and its leadership were at least willfully blind or recklessly indifferent to Gerrard’s misconduct. The firm ignored “red flags” regarding Gerrard beginning when it first hired him as a partner in 2010 and turned a blind eye to increasingly clear evidence that emerged over the following decade showing that Gerrard was involved in serious ethical violations, human rights abuses, and criminal activity, including hacking.

This dovetails with [a lawsuit brought by former WSJ reporter Jay Solomon in the District of DC](https://abovethelaw.com/job/senior-policy-manager-child-welfare-remote/), alleging that Dechert hired hackers based in India to get his emails with Azima. Solomon says those emails included “suggestive language creating a wrongful appearance of alleged improper, unethical and/or fraudulent dealings between Mr. Solomon and Mr. Azima that never occurred.” The leaking of the hacked emails cost Solomon his job.

Dechert denies the allegations, but whether the allegations prove true or not, Gerrard’s probably not getting the Dechert alumni holiday card this year.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Biglaw Firms 'Flush With Cash' Are Getting Even Bigger With Group Lateral Moves
## They've got the money, and they're using it to grow strategically.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 13, 2022 at 5:02 PMApril 13, 2022 at 11:53 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/biglaw-firms-flush-with-cash-are-getting-even-bigger-with-group-lateral-moves/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20‘Flush%20With%20Cash’%20Are%20Getting%20Even%20Bigger%20With%20Group%20Lateral%20Moves)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/biglaw-firms-flush-with-cash-are-getting-even-bigger-with-group-lateral-moves/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/biglaw-firms-flush-with-cash-are-getting-even-bigger-with-group-lateral-moves/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you aren’t moving forward, you are falling behind. It is an increasing imperative for firms to grow more as their peer firms do so. Many firms are flush with cash, and they are investing that money in growth. At the same time, about 20% of the market has had a disappointing two to three years. Those firms are increasingly becoming the outliers, and high-quality teams are starting to question whether they are on the right platform.

— Law firm consultant Kent Zimmermann of the Zeughauser Group, offering his thoughts to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/04/08/more-law-firms-are-using-large-lateral-groups-to-drive-growth-strategy/) on the recent trend that’s been spreading through Biglaw: group lateral moves. As far as even larger law firm growth is concerned, Zimmermann said Zeughauser’s merger practice is “busier than it has ever been by about four times,” and that he expects merger activity to pick up at the end of the year. “That speaks to the strategic imperative for firms to get bigger and more profitable,” he said. “Firms don’t want to get overshadowed.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# $400K Is Now The Official Market Rate For Supreme Court Clerk Bonuses
## But not everyone is thrilled that the number has climbed so high.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 15, 2018 at 10:42 AMNovember 15, 2018 at 9:53 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/400k-is-now-the-official-market-rate-for-supreme-court-clerk-bonuses/&text=$400K%20Is%20Now%20The%20Official%20Market%20Rate%20For%20Supreme%20Court%20Clerk%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/400k-is-now-the-official-market-rate-for-supreme-court-clerk-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/400k-is-now-the-official-market-rate-for-supreme-court-clerk-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Just how high will signing bonuses for Supreme Court clerks go? It was just last summer that the going the market rate rose to a new peak — [$350,000](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/supreme-court-clerk-bonuses-hit-an-incredible-new-high/) — but it’s now been confirmed that $400,000 is now the prevailing rate. Yes, you’re reading that correctly. Biglaw firms and prestigious boutiques are now willing to pay former Supreme Court clerks almost half a million dollars in bonus money just for signing on the dotted line, on top of their base salaries and regular bonuses. Former SCOTUS clerks are making almost double their Supreme bosses’ salaries. This is crazy.

We first [hinted at this trend](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/supreme-court-clerk-hiring-watch-the-complete-clerk-roster-for-october-term-2018/) back in August, when my colleague David Lat mentioned that at least six firms — Jones Day, Kirkland & Ellis, Orrick, Paul Weiss, Skadden Arps, and Susman Godfrey — were offering $400,000 bonuses to their SCOTUS clerk recruits. Michael Scanlon, hiring partner at Gibson Dunn, now confirms that “the market appears to have settled” at $400K.

Court-watchers are having trouble believing Biglaw firms are willing to pay this much money just for a new associate’s résumé line, and some have even suggested that ethics rules be consulted. Tony Mauro of the [National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/11/14/400k-for-scotus-clerks-a-bonus-too-far/) has the details:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“It’s become absurd,” said Todd Peppers, who has written books about Supreme Court clerks. “These firms can no longer credibly argue that they are compensating these former clerks for the additional education and training obtained during their Supreme Court clerkships. Yes, these former clerks are very smart. That being said, this is about access and insight into the individual chambers.”

U.C. Hastings College of the Law professor Rory Little, himself a former clerk, said, “If I were a clerk today and knew that I could get an extra almost half-million dollars, I would feel very careful about the firms’ Supreme Court cases while clerking. Seriously, an ethics expert needs to look at this carefully, under the current ethics rules and concerns we adopt for lawyers and judges in other situations. All 37 clerks or more feel that same ‘tug,’ even if it is implicit or unconscious.”

More clerks at one firm than at any other may be feeling that “tug” right now, and that’s because Jones Day just [emerged victoriously](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/11/13/jones-day-lands-a-record-11-supreme-court-law-clerks-as-associates/?cmp=share_twitter) from this year’s wooing of the SCOTUS clerks, having cornered the market after hiring 11 of them. That’s a $4.4 million investment in signing bonuses alone for a group of new hires who may wind up taking the money and running after just a few years at the firm.

As noted by Harvard Law School professor Richard Lazarus, “Jones Day is paying a lot of money for a photograph.” Oof, Jones Day needs to open up a personal injury practice group for that sick burn. Luckily for the firm, there’s a pretty big chance it’ll be staffed by some highly intelligent Supreme Court clerks.

If you know that your firm is paying $400,000 for SCOTUS clerks, [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=SCOTUS%20Clerkship%20Bonuses) (subject line: “SCOTUS Clerkship Bonuses”) or text us (646-820-8477), and we’ll compile a list of every firm that’s paying so generously for talent of Supreme proportions.

# Come Celebrate Finals, Bonuses, Or (Maybe) Raises With Us
## It's that time of year again, so let's have a holiday party!
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 22, 2023 at 1:13 PMNovember 22, 2023 at 11:23 AM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/come-celebrate-finals-bonuses-or-maybe-raises-with-us/&text=Come%20Celebrate%20Finals,%20Bonuses,%20Or%20(Maybe)%20Raises%20With%20Us)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/come-celebrate-finals-bonuses-or-maybe-raises-with-us/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/come-celebrate-finals-bonuses-or-maybe-raises-with-us/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As you start logging off for Turkey Day, it’s time to start thinking about your holiday party plans to celebrate the season. Sure, your law firm is hosting a gala event, but partying around your bosses introduces its own sort of stress. If you’re looking for something laid back in the NYC area, feel free to come hang out with Above the Law!

Here are all the details:

When: Monday, December 11th
Where: [Black Sheep](https://theblacksheepnyc.com/) at 583 3rd Ave
Time: 6:30 p.m. – 9 p.m.

Remember to [RSVP here](https://info.abovethelaw.com/atl-holiday-party-2023) because space is limited. See you there.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

####Topics
[ATL Holiday Party](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/atl-holiday-party/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Events](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/events/), [Holiday Parties](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/holiday-parties/), [Holidays & Seasons](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/holidays-seasons/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Law Schools](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/law-schools/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/)

# Biglaw Firm's New Partner Compensation Model Leads To Blockbuster Salaries
## $11 million a year? That's quite the payday.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 15, 2018 at 2:58 PMAugust 15, 2018 at 11:03 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firms-new-partner-compensation-model-leads-to-blockbuster-salaries/&text=Biglaw%20Firm’s%20New%20Partner%20Compensation%20Model%20Leads%20To%20Blockbuster%20Salaries)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firms-new-partner-compensation-model-leads-to-blockbuster-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-firms-new-partner-compensation-model-leads-to-blockbuster-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In 2015 Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson made some significant changes to the way they handle partner compensation. While the partnership was never lockstep, the changes — which were made to lure lateral talent — have led to a tripling of the nonequity partnership and growing the gap between the highest and lowest paid partner.

According to a[ report](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/08/14/pay-model-evolves-at-fried-frank-paving-way-for-outsized-earnings/) by the New York Law Journal, the firm has moved away from a points system to a target salary for each partner, and that means some blockbuster paydays for the top rainmakers:

Three legal industry sources with knowledge of some Fried Frank compensation details, speaking on condition of anonymity, told ALM that Lawrence Barshay, a top rainmaker at the firm, has lately been paid at least $11 million a year. Barshay, whose book of business is said to be more than $50 million a year, is head of Fried Frank’s asset management practice. (His brother, Scott Barshay, was reportedly paid nearly $10 million after joining Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison from Cravath, Swaine & Moore in 2016.)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Perhaps it is unsurprising given this change, but Fried Frank has picked up some notable lateral talent including finance partner Adam Summers from Cadwalader, capital markets partner Meredith Mackey from Davis Polk, real estate and distressed debt litigation partner Matthew Parrott from Katten Muchin Rosenman, and financial services litigation and enforcement partner Michael Keats from Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

David Greenwald, chairman of the firm since 2014, has said the changes were designed to reward high achievers and hold those not performing accountable:

“[T]the merit-based approach was largely aligned with the way in which we determined compensation anyway. So it made sense to formalize the process. In doing so, we are strengthening our ability to attract and retain the very best talent. A merit-based system enables us to reward the behaviors we want and to hold people accountable.”

The system winds up being a hybrid black box (and we all know the [issues those are alleged to cause](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/jones-day-hit-with-explosive-gender-discrimination-case/)) with partners receiving limited information about what their partners make:

[I]nternally, the firm reveals to partners the compensation of its 10 highest-paid partners, as well as pay to partners on the firm’s compensation committee who are not on the top 10 list, attorney sources told ALM. The firm also reveals a scattergram of anonymous partner pay so that partners can see how their pay stacks up against the rest of the partnership.

While firm management may be pleased they can attract laterals under the new system, that doesn’t mean everyone is happy. The ballooning nonequity partnership ranks and the growing disparity between highest and lowest paid partner can breed resentment says law firm management consultant Lisa Smith:

“One of the things that keep managing partners up at night is how do you get the right balance. There is a little bit of a zero-sum game,” she said. Adding the extra money given to star performance has “got to come from somewhere,” Smith said. “That’s what gives some people some pause: Can you have that big of a gap?”

Only time will tell if this change will lead to an exodus of partners from Fried Frank, hoping to find better deals at other firms.

# The 500 Largest Law Firms In America (2018)
## Size matters in the legal profession.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 28, 2018 at 12:14 PMApril 16, 2020 at 9:56 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-america-2018/&text=The%20500%20Largest%20Law%20Firms%20In%20America%20(2018))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-america-2018/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-500-largest-law-firms-in-america-2018/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There are many different and exciting ways to rank law firms. How prestigious are they? How much money are they making? How much take-home cash do partners earn? How big are they?

Yes, size matters, and because the legal profession is obsessed with every single measurable and quantifiable factor law firms have to offer, there’s obviously a ranking for that.

Today, the National Law Journal unleashed its [annual NLJ 500](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/06/28/nlj-500-2018-survey-of-the-nations-largest-law-firms/), a ranking of largest law firms in the United States covering the previous calendar year. If you’ve ever wondered about precise law firm headcounts, this is the ranking for you.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
For your counting pleasures, here are the 10 largest law firms in the United States:

- Baker McKenzie: 4,719
- DLA Piper: 3,609
- Norton Rose Fulbright: 3,339
- Hogan Lovells: 2,685
- Jones Day: 2,513
- Latham & Watkins: 2,436
- White & Case: 2,039
- Kirkland & Ellis: 1,997
- Greenberg Traurig: 1,944
- Morgan Lewis & Bockius: 1,943
Head to the [National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/06/28/nlj-500-charts-2018) if you’re curious about the firms ranked 11-500.

Congratulations go out to Baker McKenzie for employing more lawyers than any other firm. You know you’ve made it big when you’ve got more equity partners (701) than the firm that started the latest salary war has total attorneys (Milbank, 690).

# Altered Priorities And Evolving Career Paths: Are Millennial Attorneys Transforming Law Firm Culture?
## Read on to find out!
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onApril 4, 2019 at 12:46 PMApril 4, 2019 at 10:36 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/altered-priorities-and-evolving-career-paths-are-millennial-attorneys-transforming-law-firm-culture/&text=Altered%20Priorities%20And%20Evolving%20Career%20Paths:%20Are%20Millennial%20Attorneys%20Transforming%20Law%20Firm%20Culture?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/altered-priorities-and-evolving-career-paths-are-millennial-attorneys-transforming-law-firm-culture/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/altered-priorities-and-evolving-career-paths-are-millennial-attorneys-transforming-law-firm-culture/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Given the sheer numbers alone, the millennial cohort of attorneys will — inevitably and soon — overtake their elders, bringing with them their distinct perspective, working style, and outlook to bear on the future of the legal industry. It is incumbent on the legal industry to understand this generation’s motivations and priorities and adapt accordingly — not necessarily the other way around.

To help understand this changing landscape, we here at Above the Law have partnered with our friends at Major, Lindsey & Africa for the second time to field a series of surveys aimed at exploring changing law firm dynamics and highlight any generational differences between younger lawyers and their more experienced counterparts.

Fill out the form below to receive the free report detailing our findings:

# Biglaw Firm Matches Cravath Compensation For Associates Who Are 'On Scale'
## What does this mean for associates who *aren't* 'on scale'?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 24, 2022 at 3:02 PMMarch 24, 2022 at 1:46 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/alston-bird-raise-2022/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20Cravath%20Compensation%20For%20Associates%20Who%20Are%20‘On%20Scale’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/alston-bird-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/alston-bird-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Money is flying around Biglaw right now, and firms throughout the Am Law 200 continue to swoop in to match the Cravath salary scale. With associates now earning between $215,000 and $415,000, that’s a nice payday.

A little birdie told us that the latest firm to adopt the Cravath compensation system is Alston & Bird, a firm that’s currently ranked at No. 53 in the most recent Am Law 100. With $851,601,000 gross revenue in 2020, this firm can certainly afford to share its largesse with associates. This is what the new salary scale looks like at the firm:



It’s worth noting, however, that only those associates who are “on scale” will be receiving these raises. So, what does “on scale” mean here? Some of the associates we’ve heard from seem a bit wary about that language. The memo from the firm seems a bit vague, if we’re being honest.

Are these raises tied to hours? Are these raises discretionary? Could this be a match in name only? Alston & Bird associates, we’re relying on you to let us know. Please reach out to us give us your opinion on these raises. Your comments may find their way into an update (anonymously, of course).

Congrats to everyone at the firm who may (or may not) be receiving raises.

(Flip to the next page to see the memo from Alston & Bird.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# A Top Texas Firm Matches In All U.S. Offices
## A Lone Star leader steps up to the plate.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 16, 2016 at 6:34 PMJune 16, 2016 at 8:30 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/a-top-texas-firm-matches-in-all-u-s-offices/&text=A%20Top%20Texas%20Firm%20Matches%20In%20All%20U.S.%20Offices)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/a-top-texas-firm-matches-in-all-u-s-offices/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/a-top-texas-firm-matches-in-all-u-s-offices/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This doesn’t come as a huge surprise — we [predicted it](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/morning-docket-06-13-16/) a few days ago — but it’s still welcome news. We’re happy to report that [Andrews Kurth](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/andrews-kurth/) just raised associate salaries to the [Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/) scale.

The now-familiar scale starts at $180,000, for first-year and incoming associates (class of 2016), and tops out at $315,000, for eighth-year associates. Summer associates are getting bumped up as well, and it all takes effect on July 1. Salaries for counsel, of counsel, and non-U.S. associates “are being evaluated and will be addressed separately.”

One tipster was ecstatic:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[W]e have been waiting!!!! So excited, especially since most of the big historic firms in Houston have matched with the exception of Fulbright.

That’s right. If you cross Andrews Kurth off this list of [non-raising firms in Texas](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/by-region-which-top-10-vault-ranked-firms-have-not-raised-salaries-for-associates/2/), the two remaining names are Norton Rose Fulbright and Jones Day.

UPDATE (8:30 p.m.): It didn’t show up on our prior list of [Texas non-raisers](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/by-region-which-top-10-vault-ranked-firms-have-not-raised-salaries-for-associates/2/) because it’s not in the [Vault top 10 for Texas](http://www.vault.com/company-rankings/law/best-law-firms-in-each-us-region/?sRankID=14) (it’s #11), but Haynes & Boone has yet to raise pay — and we’ve heard from many HayBoo associates who asked us to underscore that fact.

Presumably Andrews Kurth’s [settlement](http://www.law360.com/articles/759999/settlement-reached-in-200m-andrews-kurth-malpractice-suit) in that [giant malpractice case](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/11/which-biglaw-firm-just-got-hit-with-a-200-million-malpractice-verdict/) wasn’t too financially onerous (or was covered in whole or in part by insurance). Congratulations, AK associates, and welcome to the [MoneyLaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/moneylaw/) club!

# Did Kanye West Find A New Biglaw Firm To Represent Him?
## Updated with a statement from the firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 27, 2022 at 3:15 PMOctober 28, 2022 at 9:16 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/did-kanye-west-find-a-new-biglaw-firm-to-represent-him/&text=Did%20Kanye%20West%20Find%20A%20New%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Represent%20Him?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/did-kanye-west-find-a-new-biglaw-firm-to-represent-him/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/did-kanye-west-find-a-new-biglaw-firm-to-represent-him/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Michael Loccisano/Getty)

This week has been full of news in the overlapping Venn diagram that is Biglaw, music, and antisemitism. That may seem like a strange combo, but strange times and all that.

As you’ve likely heard by now, Kanye West has [launched a barrage ](https://www.billboard.com/lists/kanye-west-hate-speech-consequences-timeline/celebrities-react-to-death-con-tweet/)of media appearances and social media posts espousing problematic views. There were the antisemitic attacks on social media that got him booted from Twitter. [He spread](https://www.npr.org/2022/10/19/1129747423/kanye-west-george-floyd-lawsuit) vicious, unfounded rumors that it wasn’t former police officer Derek Chauvin that caused George Floyd’s death but rather fentanyl — and as a result is facing a $250 million lawsuit. He wore a [“White Lives Matter” shirt](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/kanye-wests-white-lives-matter-drama-everything-to-know/) to his Yeezy fashion show.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
And there have been consequences. He lost deals with Balenciaga and [Adidas](https://fashionista.com/2022/10/adidas-kanye-west-partnership-ending). He was dropped by Creative Artists Agency, and film and television studio MRC announced they were ditching a completed documentary on West.

So, yeah. Ye is going to need some world-class lawyers if he’s going to bounce back from all this. But that hasn’t gone smoothly. First was the news that Kanye picked up [Johnny Depp’s former lawyer, Camille Vasquez](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/amid-fallout-from-antisemitic-rants-george-floyd-conspiracy-theories-and-more-kanye-west-turns-to-familiar-biglaw-face-for-legal-help/) of Brown Rudnick. But when the rapper declined to back off of his antisemitic remarks, t[he firm backed off the representation](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-firm-passes-on-representing-kanye-west-after-rapper-refuses-to-back-away-from-antisemitic-remarks/). Cadwalader, the firm that previously represented Ye in his split with Gap, also [distanced themselves](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/second-biglaw-firms-dump-kanye-west-over-antisemitic-remarks/) from the rapper.

But, if Kanye’s [recent Instagram post](https://www.forbes.com/sites/siladityaray/2022/10/27/kanye-west-returns-to-instagram-addresses-losing-billionaire-status-in-love-speech/) is to be believed, he may have found a Biglaw firm to represent him in his mounting legal woes.

My guess is no one told Kanye what happens to privileged material when it is shared with the world…

Hmmm, one does wonder who MF at Quinn Emanuel actually is. Of course, MF could just be a delightful, if raunchy, nickname Ye uses for this lawyer in his phone.

Ye has since deleted the Instagram story.

UPDATE: Quinn Emanuel provided the following statement:

“QE is opposed to all forms of bigotry and hate.  In the rare instance a client espouses such abhorrent views we consider whether and how we can exit the representation consistent with our ethical obligations as lawyers.”

# Morning Docket: 09.18.23
## * Texas AG Ken Paxton acquitted in his impeachment trial, which as a reminder was brought by the Republicans in the Texas House. [[Texas Tribune](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/09/16/ken-paxton-acquitted-impeachment-texas-attorney-general/)] * Don't let the Clarence and Sam ethical quagmire distract from the other important legal reporting coming out of ProPublica. Like this deep dive into how Mississippi deals with poor defendants. [[ProPublica](https://www.propublica.org/article/mississippi-courts-wont-say-how-they-provide-lawyers-for-poor-clients)] * While her fellow judges engage in an end run around the Constitution to sideline Judge Pauline Newman citing a decline in mental faculties (which a leading neurologist disputes... but obviously judges understand neurology better than neurologists), she regaled a conference with her take on patent issues surrounding vaccine development. [[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/embattled-us-appeals-judge-takes-stage-vaccine-law-conference-2023-09-15/)] * Trouble in wingnut paradise? [Doctor](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/lawyers-calling-themselves-doctor-is-still-stupid-trump-lawyer-edition/) Jenna Ellis turns on Donald Trump. [[The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/15/trump-lawyer-jenna-ellis)] * Biglaw is hemorrhaging support staff. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/09/14/the-attorney-concierge-era-for-business-development-professionals-is-over/)] * T.I. headed back to court with his IP case against a doll manufacturer now that the Supreme Court futzed with IP standards [in the dog toy case](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/if-it-looks-like-a-bottle-scotus-ruling-on-a-jack-daniels-copy-dog-is-in/). [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1722513)] * Banks tell CFPB that there's no reason to have separate standards for "medical credit cards" aimed at patients trying to not go bankrupt under the American health care system because they're really not any different than regular credit cards... despite being named "medical credit cards," marketed toward a uniquely desperate population, and having totally different policies. [[Bloomberg Law News](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/banking-law/banks-warn-cfpb-to-back-off-on-scrutiny-of-medical-credit-cards)]
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onSeptember 18, 2023 at 9:13 AM
8
